Sport shooting with an uzi? Teaching weapon safety? Ignoring the fact shes 
9 years old, why not simply use a pistol, or a 22. calibre rifle?

Allowing civilians to own all kinds of semi-automatic rifles and even fully 
automatic machine guns seems outlandish to me. Admittedly, I know very 
little about guns, but my logic tells me an uzi isn`t even very good for 
the 2nd main purpose of owning a gun; home defense, due to the fact there`s 
a greater chance the bullets will go through an assailant and a wall and 
might hit someone else. Even then, if you live alone, have really solid 
walls etc,  I also suppose, for example, a shotgun would be more effective 
against stopping someone charging at you with a knife for example, compared 
to an uzi which creates smaller wounds that have a smaller chance of 
incapacitating someone right away. 

Thus i see no logical reason for allowing civilians to own an uzi or 
semi-automatic rifles, except for of course to maintain the commercial 
interests of the companies which sell these guns. ﻿

After watching this a few times, I came to the realization that this was 
the best possible outcome.  I mean, that gun could've easily taken out 
every single bystander. 

BTW, the argument "guns are inanimate objects, they don't kill people" is 
the stupidest thing I've ever heard.  Just like knives, chainsaws, baseball 
bats, etc. are inanimate objects.  How much easier is it to kill someone 
with a gun?  Its' clean, it's precise, it's surgical.  Are you really going 
to bludgeon someone with a baseball bat?  Are you going to dismember 
someone with a chainsaw?  Will you really carve someone up with a knife?  
NO!  Guns are a different animal.  It's a disassociation because there is 
no contact with the flesh.  You can simply squeeze off a round, and end a 
life.  It's a complete disassociation with the gravity of the situation. 

Lastly, the whole "constitutional rights" argument is retarded.  Go out and 
get a rifle, or a normal handgun.  Why in the world do you need to be 
arming children with semi-automatic weapons?  I mean, is this not the same 
sort of behavior that you Americans condemn in places like Africa and the 
Middle East?  People complain about the militarization of the police, yet 
here we are arming small children with uzi's.  Good grief!  #MegaFacePalm  ﻿

I may be in the minority but there are several videos on YouTube that have 
kids younger than this girl shooting machine guns and nothing bad happened 
there. I think a kid can safely shoot a full auto gun if trained and guided 
by and instructor is well disciplined and highly competent in his judgement 
on the individual kid in question.
That said, the instructor is to blame here for very bad judgement. He did 
not take note of the girl's ability or there lack of to hold the gun on 
target, he gave the girl only one shot on semi auto before switching the 
gun to full auto with a full magazine and letting her lose, and he stood in 
front of and just above the gun's muzzle. The instructor made every mistake 
in the book here and it cost him his life.

Lesson learned: stop training your kid to be like "Hit Girl". Can't we just 
let kids be kids and not teach them how to kill until they join the army? I 
mean let them have a normal childhood. So what's the point of this 
training? So if a bunch of gangsters break into your house, you expect your

Firearm accidents like this happen every day. It's called an AD, accidental 
death. It's a tragedy what happened, but working as a instructor at a gun 
range pretty much has implied risks. Charles Vacca was not an NRA certified 
instructor and likely did not have the proper background training. This 
could just has easily been a table saw or a nail gun (yes people are trying 
to ban both of these as well).

I do agree that a 9-year old should probably work her way up to shooting an 
Uzi. This is analogous to putting your daughter on a litre sportbike 
instead of a trail-90; or the Tide Nascar vs. a 40cc gokart. 

Tragic acts happen daily and it's very upsetting to sheltered people with 
no prior experience with events such as these. This has never, and will 
never, happen at my local gun range which has proper safety protocols in 
place to prevent this. If anything positive has come out of this, it will 
be in the form of safer protocols for instructor lead training.﻿

That is not how an Uzi sounds. That's an airsoft gun. Notice, when she 
fires the first shot, that it doesn't eject a casing. also, judging from 
the way that thing looks, she would be shooting a .45 uzi. She is an eight 
year old girl. I am a grown man, and firing a .45, for me, is still enough 
to cause a little recoil. She does not have a firm grip on the firearm, and 
yet, when she fires the single round, she shows no clear sign of suffering 
from recoil.

The video also conveniently stops. right when she 'shoots' him, but the 
audio continued to play for another half second. No matter what, this was 
edited.

Also, take note of the sound of the breach being closed at the beginning of 
the tape, and how it does not correspond with his hand movements at all, 
since the release is near the bolt, and not the grip. And also take note of 
the sound of the gun hitting the ground at the end. Both sounds are very 
loud, even though the camera is suffering from wind buffeting, which would 
distort any audio reaching it. The two simulated weapon sounds are much 
louder than the instructor speaking, who is at a range of at least ten feet 
from the recording device, and yelling in order for the girl, who is 
wearing around-ear earmuffs, to be able to hear him.

The argument for guns is very simple.  It is not for hunting; it is not for 
entertainment; it is not even for protecting common citizens from 
criminals.  Americans have guns for the simple reason that it gives them 
some power in case their government ever becomes a tyranny.  That was the 
original intention of the second amendment.  It is a simple and valid 
purpose.  Anyone who thinks our government will never become a tyranny is 
naive, and only needs to study history to see that tyrannies are an always 
present threat.  Some people will try to make the issue murky by saying 
that the second amendment is for hunting.  No, it's not.  It's to protect 
citizens from the government.  Guns are deadly, and accidents will happen, 
but just because the stove in your home can catch fire doesn't mean that 
you should remove it.  The second amendment right, like a gun, is not 
something that we use everyday, but if we need to use it one day and don't 
have it, then you will regret why you were cajoled into giving it up.﻿

recoil.  The Uzi is NOT a good starter weapon.  Yes it is small but as 
proven by this incident, it bucks quite a bit when fired full auto. 
 Something like a tripod or bipod, fired from prone, would be a better 
starter weapon.  Personal opinion is that children below a certain age

auto weapons should be reserved for those who understand the basics of 
firearm safety, since they are inherently more difficult to use safely..﻿

I'm an American and even I say "stupid Americans." Who in their right mind 
thinks it's okay to give a 9 year old girl a *FUCKING FULL-AUTO SUBMACHINE 
GUN UZI?* Gun culture in this country exceeds all reasonableness. You know 
what a 9 year old should be doing instead of shooting a submachine gun? 
Riding a bicycle, playing sports, running, going swimming. The comments 
defending *children* shooting guns are pathetic and are out of the realm of 
intelligence. If this was an Iraqi child with an Iraqi instructor, the same 
dumbasses defending this girl from shooting an Uzi would be stereotyping 
the Middle East by saying they're terrorist training and saying snide 
remarks such as "where's your Allah now?"  
Dumbasses. ﻿

instructor's family, but also for the little girl and HER family. But I 
must say this: Why do news organizations always feel they have to go to a 
freeze frame, and not let us see the climactic moment, when something like 
this happens. Post a clear warning under the video about it being very 
graphic, then let people make up their own minds about watching it. Stop 
censoring the news!﻿

He has his left hand under the magazine, in theory attempting to stabilize 
or help hold the Uzi in place - VERY bad decision.  With his hand 
supporting the mag, as soon as the gun started to climb, the girl lost her 
grip on the front stock (which isn't much of a grip on an Uzi pistol 
anyway), and the gun climbed up and to the left because his own hand was 
the only thing supporting it, thus directing it towards himself.  Uzi's 
naturally climb up and to the left on their own due to their high cyclic 
rate, this was a fatally bad position for the "instructor" to place himself 
in.  NEVER stand next to someone firing a full-auto weapon, regardless of 
their age or experience.  I've owned and fired full-auto guns for twenty 
years, this man sealed his own fate.﻿

I disagree with how this girl was introduced to the Uzi though. I am not 
saying no kid is competent enough to shoot a  full auto Uzi. It can be done 
safely. There are many videos on YouTube of kids shooting machine guns 
safely.
If it were my kid in that situation I would have first made her shoot a 
Ruger 10/22 rifle with a shooting rest to start, then moved on to a Ruger 
SR 22 pistol, then a Glock 19 9mm pistol, then I would ease her into 
shooting faster with that pistol. Then I would ease her into the full auto 
realm with a longer barreled MP5 and only with myself or an instructor 
holding tight on the gun with her and only a few rounds at a time to start. 
I would then gradually scale up the number of rounds shot each time. Then I 
would after it is clear I do not need to help her hold the gun on target I 
will step back out of the way and allow her to shoot the MP5 in full auto 
unaided. After it was clear she had mastered handling the heavier MP5 would 
I allow her to shoot an Uzi and then only a few rounds at a time and with
